citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of the inspection, multiple animals were observed with unresolved health and veterinary care issues.
-A juvenile wallaby’s right ear is visibly swollen and hanging abnormally. The APHIS inspector observed the animal
repeatedly shaking its head. When questioned, the facility representative stated the swelling was first noticed
approximately two weeks earlier and was believed to be the result of trauma. The facility had not contacted the Attending
Veterinarian regarding the condition, and no treatment had been provided.
-An ostrich was observed lying down in the enclosure and unable to rise. The facility representative reported that the
animal is unable to stand unassisted and requires human assistance at least three times daily to access food and water.
The Veterinarian examined the ostrich three weeks prior and prescribed antibiotics; however, the animal’s condition had
not improved, and the facility had not conducted any follow-up consultation with the Veterinarian.
All exhibitors must ensure that all animals are provided with adequate veterinary care to prevent, control, diagnose, and
treat diseases and injuries. Failure to provide adequate veterinary care can result in unnecessary suffering resulting from
the delays in treatment of impacted animals, as occurred with this wallaby and Ostrich. Correct by ensuring that this
wallaby and ostrich are examined and diagnosed by a veterinarian and that the treatment plan is followed according to
their instructions.
To be corrected by close of business on July 3, 2025.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C license. This inspection report is limited to the Direct non-compliances
identified during that inspection. An additional inspection report will be delivered with the other issues identified during this
inspection. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with a facility representative.
Regulated activity cannot continue under your existing USDA license as it is expired.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
At the time of the inspection, multiple animals were observed with unresolved health and veterinary care issues. 
 
-A juvenile wallaby’s right ear is visibly swollen and hanging abnormally. The APHIS inspector observed the animal 
repeatedly shaking its head. When questioned, the facility representative stated the swelling was first noticed 
approximately two weeks earlier and was believed to be the result of trauma. The facility had not contacted the Attending 
Veterinarian regarding the condition, and no treatment had been provided.  
-An ostrich was observed lying down in the enclosure and unable to rise. The facility representative reported that the 
animal is unable to stand unassisted and requires human assistance at least three times daily to access food and water. 
The Veterinarian examined the ostrich three weeks prior and prescribed antibiotics; however, the animal’s condition had 
not improved, and the facility had not conducted any follow-up consultation with the Veterinarian.  
 
All exhibitors must ensure that all animals are provided with adequate veterinary care to prevent, control, diagnose, and 
treat diseases and injuries. Failure to provide adequate veterinary care can result in unnecessary suffering resulting from 
the delays in treatment of impacted animals, as occurred with this wallaby and Ostrich. Correct by ensuring that this 
wallaby and ostrich are examined and diagnosed by a veterinarian and that the treatment plan is followed according to 
their instructions. 
 
To be corrected by close of business on July 3, 2025. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C license. This inspection report is limited to the Direct non-compliances 
identified during that inspection. An additional inspection report will be delivered with the other issues identified during this 
inspection. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Regulated activity cannot continue under your existing USDA license as it is expired.
